review_title: Good Place to Work in Good Times
pros: Great benefits, competitive pay, flexible schedules. In good times, they really are a great place to work.
cons:
- Flexible schedule doesn't mean you don't work extra hours, you just have more say in how to split it up. You will be working round the clock if you don't have a supportive manager to push back for you.
- Very hierarchical - decisions and information is shared depending on job level, not job responsibilities. If you are a manager running a project, you are not included in conversations that impact your work. Even at Director and above, autonomy in satellite regions are limited if you have a manager elsewhere.
- Very US-centric. Standards and policies are all very focused on US customs even if they make no sense in the region.
- Poor crisis management and communication. COVID has really hit the company hard and they have not lived up to their best places to work reputation. Whilst it is understandable that they were blindsided as everyone was, senior management should have focused more on internal comms than external comms.

review_title: Hilton Japan: Harassment, Calls on the Weekend and Unpaid Overtime
pros: -Travel benefits (room rate and F&B discounts, etc.) -Values (although, Hilton values are not followed by people who work there)
cons: I know experiences vary from property to property to property, but I would advise Job Seekers to stay away.  Hotels where I worked (Hilton Osaka, Hilton Nagoya) were plagued by micromanaging, incompetent leadership. Management singled out and berated staff (including myself) during meetings in front of the entire team. Team members were often guilted/berated for taking PTO or sick leave. Management harasses team members with phone calls after hours and on their days off. Even when justified overtime was worked, management would ask employees to modify timesheet to reduce or in some cases, completely erase worked overtime hours. When I tried to submit resignation with 1 month notice, management refused to accept and stated that "the company decides the last working day", forcing me to involve HR in order to carry out the resignation. Junior managers also attempted to delay delivery of said resignation notice. Lastly, pay is generally low, and company is stingy with overtime and pay raises.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Key West, FL
pros: Unlimited PTO, free employee meals. Travel room rates.
cons: Pay in Key West area is very low for housing and other expenses ( very expensive rents n over all food, gas: HR on my location is terrible. all aspects , pay, raise are almost nonexistent. Promotions are a joke, I am a supervisor and make less then most of my staff. hotel does across the board raises but supervisors are not included in the raise “ we are management “ I am an hourly paid employee and should be granted this type of raise. I applied for a manager position and got a smoke and mirror show. HR does not give employees the training necessary to advance to the next level. HR states to you interviewed well but we are still actively interviewing. Hilton promotes advancing from within, yeah if your in their click. These promotion are not based on ability but rather what management and EC wants. Hire directors that actually have experience in the hotel industry.

review_title: Good from far but far from good
job_title: Manager, Talent Research in Washington, DC
pros: Exposure to emerging recruiting/sourcing tools like Seekout and hireEZ
cons: Where to begin: 1. Too many meetings: recruiters are expected to attend 12-15 meetings per week (for 30 minutes or more), many of which are to provide updates on REQ progress 2. Too many reports: recruiters are expected to create weekly [manual] reports for each individual REQ quantifying their activity for the week (# of LinkedIn messages, # of responses, discussions, phone screens, submittals, and declines); it is the equivalent of counting beans. 3. Tracking individual candidate progress in a CRM application (Phenom) that is separate from their ATS application (Taleo). 4. There was a general disregard for an individual's efforts and time. There were multiple occasions per week where meetings would conflict w/the lunch hour (where they would start at 12pm or 12:30pm). There was one occasion where my meetings were scheduled from 11am-2pm ET with consecutive meetings. I also had meetings that were scheduled for 5-5:30pm ET (without any advanced inquiry regarding personal or family commitments after business hours). All of this is part of a general pattern of disregard for recruiters, their efforts, and time.

review_title: False Advertising for Jobs and Horrible Managment
pros: Only perks were the hotel discounts and free parking they offer to employees. They will try to offer all these cool incentives but really it’s just a ruse to make the employees feel good.
cons: Horrible management. Not flexible with any schedule you give them that was outside of THEIR preference. If you called out because you were sick, they punished you. If you were one minute early or late, they punished you. The managers are nowhere to be found when needing answers or support even if you call them. Good luck. The HR team is a complete and utter disaster. No support for the team or when receiving complaints. Nothing done about the complaints currently in motion. They shrugged their shoulders, dropped the pen they were writing with and said, “if you don’t like it, you can leave. There’s the door.” What HR team says that??? The managers do not support their team or help them in any way. There is no communication within the team nor within the managers. Asking for time off is a joke. Don’t waste your time with working at specific location unless you’re perfectly healthy and have nothing to do with your time and have no kids, no second job, no school, etc but be at their beck-and-call. I am currently waiting on a call back and it’s been well over a week with NO communication whatsoever with this team and this location.

job_title: Director of Sales and Marketing in Dallas, TX
pros: Hilton provides solid benefits, but pretty typical. The best benefit that differentiates itself from others is their associate travel program which offers low rates on rooms and 50% off (most) restaurants at hotels. The only struggle to use it is difficult hours/long hours and being understaffed in order to take time off to utilize it. Solid diversity in work place and a pretty inclusive culture. Would recommend if looking at joining the organization.
cons: For hourly associates, you tend to get schedules very late making it difficult to make plans in your personal life. For salary employees, the industry is very understaffed, since CoViD, and you will find yourself doing multiple jobs or hourly roles in addition to yours as your pay is not impacted based on how much you work. If you have a family, then it is a strain in regard to how many hours are expected of you and the times of those hours as well - throw in a commute and you rarely see your family. That being said, this is the norm throughout the industry and not just with Hilton.

review_title: Overall Good place to work...with exceptions
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Excellent benefits including continuing education and 401k matching and stock options. .Friendly and accepting corporate culture. If you are young and just starting your career journey, this is the place to go.
cons: Hilton truly does try to embody a family-like corporate culture. This makes it hard to leave if you are dissatisfied with other aspects of your job. I am overeducated for the position I have, but have only ever been allowed to make lateral moves. I am an older employee. I believe this is why. They raised salaries for entry level employees, but not for current employees. Though we are told that our feedback is valued, that is only true if it is completely positive. Metrics used to evaluate customer service include being downgraded if a customer has a complaint that cannot be resolved within company policy and negative reviews that have nothing to do with the agent. These issues are specific to this position. Hours are usually unpredictable making life/work balance difficult.

pros: Love the initiative and creativity I can use in my position

pros: As a Hilton property, you could get most hotels for $35 per night for personal travel at other Hilton properties.
cons: The sales office was closed for 6 holidays per year and on weekends. We were not allowed to work on holidays, but we were only given 4 days of vacation time (holidays were unpaid), and we did not have sick leave. We also had to rotate Saturdays even if there were no scheduled events and the office was closed. I was grossly underpaid for the area and for my sales goal. Turnover was extremely high. The CEO (Richard Abernathy) literally said "go fund me is a great resource" when people were asking for sick leave. I have heard that some of these things are better now, but it says a lot about the people at the corporate office when it takes a global pandemic to treat employees well.

We also had to rotate Saturdays even if there were no scheduled events and the office was closed. I was grossly underpaid for the area and for my sales goal. Turnover was extremely high. The CEO (Richard Abernathy) literally said "go fund me is a great resource" when people were asking for sick leave. I have heard that some of these things are better now, but it says a lot about the people at the corporate office when it takes a global pandemic to treat employees well.

job_title: Guest Services Agent in Austin, TX
pros: I really enjoyed the benefits available, including the PTO time. The discounts at Hilton properties was by far my favorite and best perk I have ever had at any job. I also was really a fan of the career track. Once you were in a position for six months you were eligible to apply for open roles. I also particularly loved my property's empowerment and backing of the front desk, to avoid having to escalate guest issues to management by default. I genuinely enjoyed the work I did at each of the Hilton properties I worked at. I was never dreadful about the work day ahead and enjoyed how each day brought something new, despite performing the same task on end.
cons: Pay required me to have a second source of income to survive. I was put on furlough in March 2020, after August our property's general manager stopped sending monthly updates. Those updates helped me feel connected to my career. I never heard from my supervisors or peers during my during my furlough. I was still a few months into my role by the time my furlough came about, however I thought I would still get an update or check in from my team. It made me feel really disconnected from a job that was positioning me for what I thought was going to be long a career with Hilton. It took the human element out of it for me.

review_title: Good place to start, little room to grow
pros:
-Pay is decent
- Plenty of hours since the hotel brings a lot of business in the area
- Benefits are nice, (Health Insurance, Dental, Vision, Holiday Pay)
- You get to meet many Hilton Executives from the HQ next door, people who actually stand for the brand and display positive work culture values.
cons:
- Very little room for growth at this property, they claim that there is always room for growth. However people that are willing to do the work and learn never get a chance and they would rather bring someone in with "experience" despite people within knowing much more about the property and how the hotel functions.
-HR always seems to have a hidden agenda and is never on your side, its always protecting the interests of the company. They will take sides and won't let you plead your side if you ever get in trouble. You're always looked as a villain.
-Management in charge of front desk front desk are selfish. They seem to have forgotten what Hilton is about and function based upon their own interests. They do what is best for them, not what is best for the employee or the company.

review_title: Hilton Baltimore Inner Harbor is a Toxic Workplace and Will Sabotage Your Career Before They'll Help You Succeed
job_title: Event Sales Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros:
The Hilton Go Honors Program and its hotel discounts (you get 30 days at a low team member rate and 70 days at a friends & family rate).

There are a lot of good people in service positions who do their jobs, care about the customers, and support their team members. They also have some directors and managers who know how to lead, but they seem to be few and far between.

If you want to make money, you'll make good money here. But be careful of the cost. Fighting for your job because you care about the hotel business and want to do the right things isn't enough to keep it unfortunately. If anyone deems you as a problem or is jealous of your success, they will sabotage you by playing "run and tell that" to your boss or someone else in leadership.

If you're friendly and great at customer service, you'll make a lot of friends and money here, but don't make the mistake of thinking your personality will save you. If you're a threat to anyone, you're on the short list to be outed.
cons:
HR is THE worst! This hotel is too top-heavy with directors and assistant directors to be efficient or profitable. If you're looking for a company that will treat you like a human instead of a body, they'll give you a great song and dance about Hilton caring about its employees and leading through its brand standards. But they won't follow them. It's just PR and show-boating, but in practice, if you go to them for help, be prepared for being disappointed for their lack of responsiveness after you call them, email them, and talk to them in-person yet they STILL won't resolve your need with any urgency or act like they know the answer you seek, when they are supposed to know their job, plus act like they will find out for you.

From Hilton's core values to Thrive @ Work, this location thrives off of toxicity, two-faced "smile in your face, stab you in the back" drama, and will gaslight you into thinking you're the problem instead of doing their job, putting out fires, and solving problems by creating a healthy environment where everyone can reach their potential. Owned by the City of Baltimore and supported by the Unite Here 7 union, this hotel was supposed to added to the city's economic development and help fill its coffers but it's renigged on its purpose to do just that for most of its existence. How does a hotel like this bearing the cache of the Hilton name and being centrally located on primetime real estate next to the LightRail, Camden Yards, and down the street from the Inner Harbor... STILL not gain a profit?

One critical reason: Their hypocritical approach towards making the employees happy is made even worse because they refuse to get rid of the bad eggs, which frustrates middle management because they get NO help from the union or upper leadership to make the work environment better for ALL. As a result, the bad eggs make management jobs harder and more stressful, tensions between employees is strained, which leads to poor customer service. All these factors contribute to profit loss and poor customer retention. However, because Maryland is an at-will state, if you're not a unionized worker, they can fire you at their leisure for whatever reason they legitimize in their heads because they legally can. Regardless if you're a competent, industrious, and dedicated employee or not. And they refuse to give you the resources that you need to do your job the RIGHT way (instead of their janky, unprofessional way). 

For a property like this that eats its young, doesn't train or onboard new employees with any consistency or competence (unless they've been in the role long enough that the job is muscle memory), you start to wonder why they're even in hospitality and tourism, if they not trying to do the work. One reason, Hilton's benefits are industry-leading and compared to most hotels in the area and other jobs, they can't be beat. Yet more than a few staff on the executive team rather learn and earn at the expense of everyone else to maintain the status quo without the initiative to do whatever it takes to stimulate recovery. The American Hotel and Lodging Association says that recovery in the hospitality sector isn't slated to rebound until 2024. Then, why isn't the executive team pulling out all the stops to make the hotel profitable NOW?! What are they waiting for?

Under these circumstances, it's no wonder that the Hilton Baltimore Inner Harbor has struggled for YEARS and hemorrhaged money since its inception with only 2017-2019 being the exception. Yet a modest profit of $1.3 million wasn't due to the hotel changing for the better and earning that surplus with money-making programs, increasing bookings, or improving customer retention. Hilton Baltimore Inner Harbor only made a profit after a round of cost-cutting and refinancing the hotel in order to lower interest rates and its tax burden.

If that doesn't wreak of chronic mismanagement and abysmal leadership, then I don't know what does.

pros:
The overall company posture seems well. The CEO is actually engaged, and the company has various resources available to employees. 

If you want to get paid a "decent" salary to essentially stoplight your career for a few years, this is the place to do it at.

Thankfully the security program is at least 7-10 years behind the industry, so it does not require much thought to complete the work. Now this could be good or bad depending on where you are in your career.
cons:
Mid level management has to be the world leading in how awful they are. 

The overall direction of the security program is slow and everything flows through roughly 3 people. There is no investment from mid level management into you as a person. They are focused on enriching themselves first, and could care less how their direct reports are developing in their career.

Meet HR early and remember who to speak with you are bound to hear either racist, sexist, unprofessional or flat out inappropriate conversation throughout your time at the organization.

review_title: Some good, some bad...what do you value?
pros: Strong brand recognition. When quality suffers, guests will let you know. But if you work at a great hotel and people know it, that means something, too. Great perks for both salaried and hourly employees.
cons: Like the rest of the industry, suffers from high turnover and unnecessary drama at the GM/AGM level. Mgmt often has difficulty retaining employees because shift leaders who know how to hide unproductivity are rewarded - given extra days off, given premium shifts - while those going the extra mile for guests don't see raises. Other times, salaried employees are retained whose work ethic sabotages the bottom line...but if they know people, they know people. Find out if the hotel you work for is about the $$. Then ask (yourself) if employees throughout the franchise are working toward that. If it's about the culture, then ask about that. If it's something else, then ask about that, too. If there is any inconsistency, then mgmt is prioritizing something other than the brand: look out

pros:
PTO program is nice with regularly accruing, rolling hours. 
A big effort to have fun on-site events for team.
Ability to move to different departments, positions, or hotels anywhere.
cons:
Handling of COVID was atrocious internally. The company laid off thousands of people, expected those remaining to do quadruple the work, failed to communicate to anyone what the long term plan was for return to work, and then the CEO has the nerve to tout financial gains in 2020. Gross.
Salaried management positions are grossly underpaid compared to other industries, especially for a company expecting managers to work a minimum of 50 hours per week.
They will slowly milk out every last ounce of effort from anyone. 
They flex on work/life balance, but there is NO work life balance as long as you are cutting hourly schedules.
You could give everything and you're still only a number and replaceable.
Corporate is a mess. Any directives and standards are not planned well, not tested, rolled out in a wild way and the Lobby constantly has contradicting standards documents.
